senses.sense_definition: Relating to the reign of King William III of England (1689â€“1702) or to the faction that supported him against James II.

examples.text: The <w>Williamite</w> forces secured a decisive victory at the Battle of the Boyne.
Historians often analyze the <w>Williamite</w> settlement to understand the political shifts of the late 17th century.

senses.sense_definition: Describing a style of architecture or furniture characteristic of the reign of William III, often featuring specific baroque elements.

examples.text: The museum displays a rare collection of <w>Williamite</w> furniture from the late 17th century.
Her house features a beautiful <w>Williamite</w> staircase that has been carefully preserved.

senses.sense_definition: Describing antique glassware engraved with the portrait or symbols of King William III, often used historically to toast his memory.

examples.text: Collectors prize genuine <w>Williamite</w> glasses for their historical significance and intricate engravings.
The auction included a rare <w>Williamite</w> goblet used for toasting the king's memory.

senses.sense_definition: A supporter of King William III of England, particularly during the Glorious Revolution and the subsequent wars in Ireland.

examples.text: The <w>Williamites</w> celebrated their victory after the long military campaign.
As a staunch <w>Williamite</w>, he refused to acknowledge the claims of the exiled king.

senses.sense_definition: A member of the Hermits of Saint William, a religious order founded by the followers of William of Maleval in the 12th century.

examples.text: The <w>Williamites</w> eventually adopted the Benedictine Rule to integrate with the wider church structure.
Historical records show that a community of <w>Williamites</w> lived in this valley during the Middle Ages.

senses.sense_definition: A member of the Order of Monte Vergine, a religious order founded by William of Montevergine.

examples.text: The <w>Williamites</w> of Monte Vergine are known for their white habits.
Saint William founded the order, and his disciples became known as <w>Williamites</w>.
